content.description: Start standing at the blunt overhung arete on the laser cut face. Reach up, and just right of the arete there is a small sloped crimp. Pull on, and follow a line of similarly difficult crimps up and left to the apex of the boulder for a relatively easy topout. This will take a really strong crimper to take down this line, which should easily be into the double digits. A variant also likely exist heading up and right from the starting crimp.
content.protection: Pads and maybe a spotter. It's pretty tall.
content.location: It lies by the overhanging, blunt arete on the obvious laser cut face. This is an inspiring but wildly difficult line.

content.description: This is a quirky, little boulder problem which is actually super fun. It's a good way to practice for the two most classic boulders at Pawtuckaway, incorporating a bat hang like Overlooked, V4, and a similar mantel finish as for Ride The Lightning, V6 (just not fifteen feet off the deck). Naturally the problem isn't nearly as good as the aforementioned climbs, but it does climb incredibly well for being so tiny.Sit start on a ledge just above the ground, and kick your feet up above your head into a bat hang on the lip. Pull a hand onto the lip to match with your feet, and then flip your body around in order to make an awesome high footed mantel.
content.location: Looking at the blank face, round the boulder to the right. Step over another boulder, and you'll see a little alcove in which Head Over Heels starts. The start hold is obvious.

content.description: Home of some of the hardest routes in the Douglas State Forest, a few of which are easily into the double digits. This is a massive boulder with a huge, twenty degree overhung, laser cut face.
